articles.title: Emergency aid of 50 million euros mobilized by the EU for farmers in Bulgaria, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, and Romania
articles.summary: The European Commission allocates funds from the agricultural reserve for farmers affected by adverse climatic events.
articles.content:
Brussels – The European Commission adopted, on Friday, a proposal to provide nearly 50 million euros from the agricultural reserve to support farmers in the fruit and vegetable sector in Bulgaria, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, and Romania who have recently suffered significant damage due to adverse weather phenomena, according to a press release from the community executive.

Following approval by the member states, the Commission’s proposal allocates 7.4 million euros to Bulgaria, 10.8 million euros to Hungary, 4.2 million euros to Latvia, 1.1 million euros to Lithuania, 14.8 million euros to Poland, and 11.5 million euros to Romania. These countries can complement this EU support with up to 200% from national funds.

In all six member states, late frosts, which were often followed by hail or heavy rains, have destroyed a large part of the fruit, vegetable, nut, and seed crops.

Today’s aid will bring some relief to farmers who have lost their crops and income this year, said the Commissioner for Agriculture and the Food Sector, Christophe Hansen.

To ensure the effectiveness of this exceptional measure, it is important that beneficiaries receive emergency financial support quickly. Payments to farmers for the emergency financial support granted to Bulgaria, Latvia, Lithuania, Hungary, Poland, and Romania must be made before April 30, 2026.

Within the agricultural reserve, as part of the current Common Agricultural Policy (2023-2027), at least 450 million euros per year are available to help farmers cope with market disruptions or exceptional events affecting production or distribution. In its proposal for the next CAP (2028-2034), the Commission intends to double the crisis reserve to support the resilience of European farmers and the agri-food sector in the face of market disruptions. (10.10.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant and concrete action by the European Commission to provide emergency financial aid to farmers across multiple countries affected by adverse climatic events. This support helps sustain agricultural livelihoods and food production, benefiting a broad population and addressing climate-related challenges. The article provides clear details on the funding amounts, affected countries, and the policy framework, demonstrating meaningful impact and substance.
articles.personality_title: EU mobilizes €50 million emergency aid to support farmers hit by bad weather
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Recently, farmers in six European countries—Bulgaria, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, and Romania—faced serious problems because of bad weather. Late frosts, hail, and heavy rains destroyed many fruit, vegetable, nut, and seed crops, causing big losses.

**What happened** – On Friday, the European Commission decided to give nearly 50 million euros from its agricultural reserve to help these farmers. Each country will receive a specific amount, like 14.8 million euros for Poland and 7.4 million euros for Bulgaria. The countries can also add more money from their own budgets to support their farmers.

**Impact** – This financial aid will help farmers recover by replacing some of the money they lost when their crops were damaged. It shows how the EU can act quickly to support farming communities during emergencies caused by climate problems. The aid also protects food production and farmers’ incomes in these countries.

**What’s next step** – The member countries need to approve the plan and then make sure the money reaches farmers before April 30, 2026. Looking ahead, the EU plans to increase this kind of emergency fund in the next Common Agricultural Policy, aiming to better protect farmers from future crises.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The European Commission is providing urgent financial support of €50 million to farmers in six countries to help them recover from severe weather damage and secure their livelihoods.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'UE mobilise 50 millions d'euros d'aide d'urgence pour les agriculteurs touchés par le mauvais temps
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Récemment, des agriculteurs de six pays européens—Bulgarie, Hongrie, Lettonie, Lituanie, Pologne et Roumanie—ont subi de graves problèmes à cause du mauvais temps. Des gelées tardives, de la grêle et de fortes pluies ont détruit de nombreuses cultures de fruits, légumes, noix et graines, causant d'importantes pertes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Vendredi, la Commission européenne a décidé d'allouer près de 50 millions d'euros issus de la réserve agricole pour aider ces agriculteurs. Chaque pays recevra une somme précise, comme 14,8 millions d'euros pour la Pologne et 7,4 millions pour la Bulgarie. Les pays peuvent aussi compléter cette aide avec des fonds nationaux.

**Impact** – Cette aide financière permettra aux agriculteurs de se remettre en remplaçant une partie de l'argent perdu à cause des dégâts sur leurs cultures. Cela montre que l'UE peut agir rapidement pour soutenir les communautés agricoles lors d'urgences liées au climat. L'aide protège aussi la production alimentaire et les revenus des agriculteurs dans ces pays.

**Prochaine étape** – Les pays membres doivent approuver le plan, puis s'assurer que l'argent parvienne aux agriculteurs avant le 30 avril 2026. À l'avenir, l'UE prévoit d’augmenter ce type de fonds d'urgence dans la prochaine Politique Agricole Commune pour mieux protéger les agriculteurs face aux crises.

**Phrase clé** – La Commission européenne apporte un soutien financier urgent de 50 millions d'euros à six pays pour aider les agriculteurs à se remettre des dégâts causés par le mauvais temps et sécuriser leurs moyens de subsistance.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE moviliza 50 millones de euros en ayuda de emergencia para agricultores afectados por el mal tiempo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Recientemente, agricultores en seis países europeos—Bulgaria, Hungría, Letonia, Lituania, Polonia y Rumania—enfrentaron problemas graves debido al mal tiempo. Heladas tardías, granizo y fuertes lluvias destruyeron muchos cultivos de frutas, verduras, nueces y semillas, causando grandes pérdidas.

**Qué pasó** – El viernes, la Comisión Europea decidió destinar casi 50 millones de euros de la reserva agrícola para ayudar a estos agricultores. Cada país recibirá una cantidad específica, como 14,8 millones de euros para Polonia y 7,4 millones para Bulgaria. Los países también pueden sumar fondos nacionales para apoyar a sus agricultores.

**Impacto** – Esta ayuda financiera ayudará a los agricultores a recuperarse, reemplazando parte del dinero perdido por los daños en sus cultivos. Muestra cómo la UE puede actuar rápido para apoyar a las comunidades agrícolas en emergencias causadas por el clima. La ayuda también protege la producción de alimentos y los ingresos de los agricultores.

**Próximo paso** – Los países miembros deben aprobar el plan y asegurarse de que el dinero llegue a los agricultores antes del 30 de abril de 2026. De cara al futuro, la UE planea aumentar este tipo de fondos de emergencia en la próxima Política Agrícola Común para proteger mejor a los agricultores de futuras crisis.

**Frase clave** – La Comisión Europea brinda un apoyo financiero urgente de 50 millones de euros a agricultores de seis países para ayudarlos a recuperarse de los daños causados por el mal tiempo y asegurar sus medios de vida.

articles.title: International Dance Festival in Albania show for communities, Gonzato: We confirm inclusivity
articles.summary: Supported by the European Union, this year's edition takes contemporary dance out of the usual spaces, for the benefit of communities living in different parts of the city.
articles.content:
Supported by the European Union, this year’s edition takes contemporary dance out of the usual spaces, for the benefit of communities living in different parts of the city.

The International Dance Festival, under the artistic direction of the renowned choreographer of Albanian origin, Angelin Preljocaj, marked its first performances in Tirana by bringing together the most famous European and Albanian choreographers.

Supported by the European Union, this year’s edition takes contemporary dance out of the usual spaces, benefiting communities living in different parts of the city.

The EU delegation in Tirana highlighted that by bringing dance closer to communities, the joint commitment to inclusivity is reaffirmed.

For this reason, the festival’s opening took place in the premises of the Community Center “Let’s Stay Together,” featuring “G.U.I.D.” by Ballet Preljocaj, a performance that adapts to the space and transforms everyday environments into stages for all.

“Ballet, when brought to public spaces, can transcend generations and build bridges between cultures, nationalities, or worldviews. It is a universal language that everyone can understand, breaking down barriers and connecting people in ways that words often cannot. This is the true beauty of this art,” said the EU ambassador in Tirana, Slvio Gonzato, at the festival’s opening.

Present at this event, the Albanian Minister of Tourism, Culture, and Sports, Blendi Gonxhja, stated that when culture meets the community, every emotion and story becomes shared, a reminder that art belongs to everyone and can touch every heart.

The artistic director of the festival, choreographer Angjelin Preljocaj, commenting on the start of this artistic event, said that the festival aims to bring the art of dance closer to families, youth, and marginalized groups, creating exchanges and new bridges of communication between artists and citizens in their daily lives.

This is the first week of the 4th edition of this festival. Throughout the festival days, the latest creations of over 13 choreographers and international companies will be showcased over 3 weeks. The program opened with 4 public performances in the city and 5 shows on the stages of the Metropol Theatre and the National Theatre of Opera and Ballet.

The festival will run from October 9 to 25 and will offer free performances in public spaces throughout the city of Tirana. (October 10)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on an inclusive cultural event supported by the European Union that brings contemporary dance to diverse communities in public spaces, fostering social cohesion, cultural exchange, and accessibility to the arts for marginalized groups and the general public. The event has broad social significance and detailed context about its scope and impact.
articles.personality_title: International Dance Festival in Tirana brings art to all neighborhoods
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The International Dance Festival in Tirana, Albania, is a yearly event that showcases contemporary dance. This year, the festival is supported by the European Union and focuses on reaching people in different parts of the city, not just traditional theaters.

**What happened** – Starting October 9, the festival opened with performances in public spaces, including a community center called “Let’s Stay Together.” Famous choreographers from Europe and Albania joined the event, led by artistic director Angelin Preljocaj. The festival includes over 13 choreographers and runs for three weeks with free shows in public areas and theaters.

**Impact** – By bringing dance into everyday places, the festival makes art accessible to everyone, including families, young people, and marginalized groups. The European Union ambassador in Tirana, Silvio Gonzato, said that dance can connect people across cultures and generations in ways that words cannot. This approach helps build community and encourages cultural exchange.

**What's next step** – The festival will continue until October 25, offering more free performances in public spaces around Tirana. This model of sharing art outside traditional venues could inspire other cities to make culture more inclusive and reach wider audiences.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The International Dance Festival in Tirana uses public spaces to bring contemporary dance to diverse communities, making art inclusive and accessible.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Festival international de danse de Tirana apporte l'art à tous les quartiers
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Festival international de danse de Tirana, en Albanie, est un événement annuel qui met en avant la danse contemporaine. Cette année, soutenu par l'Union européenne, le festival vise à toucher les habitants de différents quartiers de la ville, au-delà des théâtres traditionnels.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – À partir du 9 octobre, le festival a débuté avec des spectacles dans des espaces publics, dont un centre communautaire appelé « Restons ensemble ». Des chorégraphes célèbres d'Europe et d'Albanie ont participé, sous la direction artistique d'Angelin Preljocaj. Plus de 13 chorégraphes présentent leurs créations pendant trois semaines, avec des spectacles gratuits dans des espaces publics et des théâtres.

**Impact** – En amenant la danse dans des lieux du quotidien, le festival rend l'art accessible à tous, y compris aux familles, aux jeunes et aux groupes marginalisés. L'ambassadeur de l'UE à Tirana, Silvio Gonzato, a expliqué que la danse peut connecter les gens au-delà des cultures et des générations, d'une façon que les mots ne peuvent pas. Cette démarche favorise la cohésion sociale et les échanges culturels.

**Prochaine étape** – Le festival se poursuivra jusqu'au 25 octobre avec d'autres spectacles gratuits dans les espaces publics de Tirana. Ce modèle pourrait inspirer d'autres villes à rendre la culture plus inclusive et accessible.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Le Festival international de danse de Tirana utilise les espaces publics pour rendre la danse contemporaine accessible à toutes les communautés.
articles.personality_title_es: Festival Internacional de Danza en Tirana acerca el arte a todos los barrios
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El Festival Internacional de Danza en Tirana, Albania, es un evento anual que muestra danza contemporánea. Este año, apoyado por la Unión Europea, el festival busca llegar a personas en diferentes partes de la ciudad, no solo en teatros tradicionales.

**Qué pasó** – A partir del 9 de octubre, el festival comenzó con presentaciones en espacios públicos, incluyendo un centro comunitario llamado «Quedémonos juntos». Participaron coreógrafos famosos de Europa y Albania, bajo la dirección artística de Angelin Preljocaj. El festival incluye más de 13 coreógrafos y dura tres semanas con funciones gratuitas en espacios públicos y teatros.

**Impacto** – Al llevar la danza a lugares cotidianos, el festival hace que el arte sea accesible para todos, incluyendo familias, jóvenes y grupos marginados. El embajador de la Unión Europea en Tirana, Silvio Gonzato, dijo que la danza puede conectar a las personas a través de culturas y generaciones de formas que las palabras no pueden. Este enfoque ayuda a construir comunidad y fomenta el intercambio cultural.

**Próximo paso** – El festival continuará hasta el 25 de octubre, ofreciendo más funciones gratuitas en espacios públicos de Tirana. Este modelo de compartir arte fuera de los lugares tradicionales podría inspirar a otras ciudades a hacer la cultura más inclusiva y llegar a más personas.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El Festival Internacional de Danza en Tirana usa espacios públicos para llevar la danza contemporánea a comunidades diversas, haciendo el arte accesible e inclusivo.
